previous_headings: Worked example - NnG and Berwick Bank
what: Run primary function spmapper() to produce prey consumption maps for each species and optionally extract within user specified polygons
title: Worked example
code: out_kitt <- spmapper(spname = "Kittiwake", fppolys = fppolys, popscen = "baseline", tooldir = tooldir) ## |---------|---------|---------|---------|========================================= ## Warning in fpudoverlap(fppolys = fppolys, udmap = udmap): Part or all of ## footprint lies on land or outside area with UD values! out_cogu <- spmapper(spname = "Guillemot", fppolys = fppolys, popscen = "baseline", tooldir = tooldir) ## |---------|---------|---------|---------|========================================= ## Warning in fpudoverlap(fppolys = fppolys, udmap = udmap): Part or all of ## footprint lies on land or outside area with UD values! out_razo <- spmapper(spname = "Razorbill", fppolys = fppolys, popscen = "baseline", tooldir = tooldir) ## |---------|---------|---------|---------|========================================= ## Warning in fpudoverlap(fppolys = fppolys, udmap = udmap): Part or all of ## footprint lies on land or outside area with UD values!

code: par(mfrow=c(2,2))  hist(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_sim, breaks=50, col=gray(0.6), main="Kittiwake") lines(rep(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_est,2),c(0,10000),lwd=2)  hist(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_sim, breaks=50, col=gray(0.6), main="Guillemot") lines(rep(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_est,2),c(0,10000),lwd=2)  hist(out_razo$allbirds_prey_sim, breaks=50, col=gray(0.6), main="Razorbill") lines(rep(out_razo$allbirds_prey_est,2),c(0,10000),lwd=2)

title: Worked example
code: tab_kitt <- data.frame(   Species = "Kittiwake",   Estimate = out_kitt$allbirds_prey_est,    Sim_CI_Lower = as.numeric(quantile(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.025)),  # Sim_Mean = mean(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_sim),    Sim_CI_Upper = as.numeric(quantile(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.975)))  tab_cogu <- data.frame(   Species = "Guillemot",   Estimate = out_cogu$allbirds_prey_est,    Sim_CI_Lower = as.numeric(quantile(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.025)),  # Sim_Mean = mean(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_sim),    Sim_CI_Upper = as.numeric(quantile(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.975)))  tab_razo <- data.frame(   Species = "Razorbill",   Estimate = out_razo$allbirds_prey_est,    Sim_CI_Lower = as.numeric(quantile(out_razo$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.025)),   # Sim_Mean = mean(out_razo$allbirds_prey_sim),    Sim_CI_Upper = as.numeric(quantile(out_razo$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.975)))  kable(rbind(tab_kitt, tab_cogu, tab_razo))

title: Worked example
text: tool explicitly checks whether provided species names valid (including capitalisation)
code: spmapper(spname = "kittiwake", fppolys = fppolys, popscen = "baseline", tooldir = tooldir) ## Error in spmapper(spname = "kittiwake", fppolys = fppolys, popscen = "baseline", : Invalid species name: must be 'Kittiwake', 'Guillemot' or 'Razorbill'!

what: Footprints smaller than one grid cell
title: Worked example
code: fppolys <- sf::st_read(system.file("demo/North_Sea_OWF_2030_polygons", package = "spmapper")) ## Reading layer `North_Sea_OWF_2030_polygons' from data source  ##   `C:\Users\clacap\AppData\Local\Temp\RtmpSKcpkE\temp_libpath5fd4217a2ac7\spmapper\demo\North_Sea_OWF_2030_polygons'  ##   using driver `ESRI Shapefile' ## Simple feature collection with 177 features and 4 fields ## Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON ## Dimension:     XY ## Bounding box:  xmin: -269946.2 ymin: -4249826 xmax: 697913.1 ymax: -3159479 ## Projected CRS: North_Pole_Lambert_Azimuthal_Equal_Area fppolys <- fppolys[which.min(sf::st_area(fppolys)),]  spmapper(spname = "Kittiwake", fppolys = fppolys, popscen = "baseline", tooldir = tooldir) ## Error in fpudoverlap(fppolys = fppolys, udmap = udmap): Size of footprint is smaller than the size of a single grid cell - tool would not produce meaningful results in this situation

what: Modifying input parameters may impact prey mass estimates.

what: Use of spmapper at the appropriate spatial scale
title: Uses, Caveats & Limitations
text: spmapper concerns space use broad, shelf-seas scale, seabird species networks UK Ireland. spmapper generates prey consumption maps regular 2x2 km grid, Lambert azimuthal equal-area projection. Users provide polygons footprint shapefiles smaller single grid cell spmapper extract. spmapper() function return warning polygon insufficient size (.e. smaller single grid cell) provided. Note, population scale mass consumption estimated UK & Ireland combined seabird species networks correspond GPS tracking underpinning utilisation distributions (Wakefield et al., 2017). Extractions within supplied polygons therefore provide proportion prey mass taken UK & Ireland seabirds, due spatial isolation central place foraging breeding seabirds, extractions within polygons retrieve prey masses taken breeding seabirds colonies within foraging range distances. reiterate spmapper recommended use comparative tool (see ).

(2025) “Time-activity budgets energetics common guillemot, razorbill, Atlantic puffin, black-legged kittiwake”, NERC EDS Environmental Information Data Centre. https://doi.org/10.5285/07b1105a-4a14-47e3-b491-9af59be90aff Wakefield, E. D., Owen, E., Baer, J., Carroll, M. J., Daunt, F., Dodd, S. G., Green, J. ., Guilford, T., Mavor, R. ., Miller, P. ., Newell, M. ., Newton, S. F., Robertson, G. S., Shoji, ., Soanes, L. M., Votier, S. C., Wanless, S. Bolton, M. title: Methods
text: spmapper estimates, uncertainty, total prey consumed course chick-rearing period typical breeding adult bird focal species. estimates scaled give fish prey mass intake breeding population. Utilisation distributions used estimate spatial origin prey mass waters surrounding UK & Ireland. providing spatial polygons, users can interrogate resulting prey consumption maps indicate foraging value marine spatial areas breeding seabirds. underlying calculations follow following stages: 1) Estimate prey mass intake single breeding adult 2) Scale individual prey mass intake species network breeding population 3) Map spatial distribution prey consumption 4) Extraction absolute & proportional prey mass within areas interest Values underlying key behavioural energetic parameters available dataset (Leedham et al., 2025); sourcing calculation methods described full supporting documentation.

what: 1) Estimate prey mass intake by a single breeding adult
title: Methods
text: estimate mass fish prey taken single adult across full chick-rearing period, developed model considers key behavioural, energetic ecological traits typical adult species. Firstly, estimate daily energetic requirements (DER) adult, consists individual’s energetic demands, half share daily chick requirements, multiplied average number chicks per nest. Adult DER equal mean cost activity costs, weighted proportion time per day allocated core behaviours (foraging, flight, rest--sea & rest nest), addition nominal daily cost warming prey loads body temperature. Total energetic requirement per adult full chick-rearing period calculated DER multiplied species-specific chick-rearing durations (days). breeding adults typically lose mass rearing chicks, realised energy intake fish prey taken single adult across chick rearing period seasonal energy requirement minus energy provided metabolised body tissue. energy quotient calculates mass typical breeding adult, multiplied proportional change body mass across breeding season (give intermediate value absolute body mass change), multiplied energy density seabird body tissue. realised seasonal energy intake converted prey mass intake dividing product prey energy density, species’ digestive energy efficiency. described calculation applied sets species parameter values (Leedham et al., 2025) giving baseline prey mass estimates species. Additionally, prey mass intake calculation applied 60 thousand sets parameter values per species (datasets provided) randomly sampled continuous probability distributions parameter. calculations provide uncertainty prey mass estimates (2.5th 97.5th percentiles). Time-activity budgets simulated using Markov chain Montecarlo (MCMC) sampling. parameters drawn probability distributions mean values. [SEE PAPER FULL PARAMETER SAMPLING REGIME] <<<<<

what: 2) Scale individual prey mass intake to the species network breeding population
title: Methods
text: total prey mass taken breeding adults given species network individual, seasonal prey mass intake, multiplied estimates number breeding adults. UDs correspond tracking seabirds across UK & Ireland (see ; Wakefield et al., 2017), individual intake quantities scaled estimates UK & Ireland species network breeding population sizes time period corresponding GPS tracking (2010-2014). estimated breeding sizes scaling species’ breeding counts Seabird2000 full national census (Mitchell et al., 2004), change ratios derived subset colony recounts available 2010-2014 via Seabird Monitoring Programme (SMP) [CITE SMP!!!] <<<<<<<< See [PAPER] full breeding population size estimate methodology. <<<<<<< Estimates breeding population sizes include baseline, lower upper estimates.

what: 3) Map the spatial distribution of prey consumption
title: Methods
text: spatial origin prey mass consumption derived multiplying prey quantities utilisation distributions (UDs), maps proportional use marine space species. UK & Ireland scale UDs focal species produced RSPB (GPS sampling quantitative methods, see Wakefield et al., 2017).

title: spmapper
text: Offshore wind energy central UK’s renewable energy strategy projected expand substantially terms generation capacity, number area coverage offshore windfarms (OWFs). OWFs potential adverse impacts marine wildlife, including seabirds, travel forage offshore areas. Among possible impact mechanisms, OWFs may impact seabirds via displacement foraging habitat, , seabirds may avoid windfarms areas might otherwise forage. , displacement windfarms may correspond loss access prey foraging seabirds, energetic demographic consequences. breeding season—particular period breeding adults rearing chicks—energetically demanding time seabirds. Seabirds must acquire sufficient prey sustain energetic requirements, provisioning chicks fledging. Safeguarding breeding success important seabird population dynamics influences long-term resilience. —seabirds must forage areas centred breeding colony—understanding estimating potential impacts OWF-related displacement breeding season critical effective seabird conservation. possible observe foraging success sufficiently fine scales comprehensive spatial coverage empirically map seabird prey consumption, describe energetic value marine areas specific seabird species. address knowledge gap, developed spmapper, spatial planning tool indicate foraging value marine areas key seabird species breed coasts islands UK (Black-legged Kittiwake Rissa tridactyla, Common guillemot Uria aalge, Razorbill Alca torda). spmapper underpinned seabird time-activity budget energetics data collated Black-legged kittiwake Rissa tridactyla, Common guillemot Uria aalge, Razorbill Alca torda, published via NERC Environmental Information Data Centre (Leedham et al. 2025). spmapper written programming language R (R Core Team, 2017). Information cite spmapper included ‘cite’ section.

title: spmapper
text: spmapper spatial planning tool generates maps seabird prey consumption chick-rearing seabirds three species. tool generates maps calculating mass fish prey taken breeding seabirds comprising UK & Ireland species network three seabird species, according species-specific behaviour, physiology, diet, demography population size; estimates spatial origin seabird prey removal according models marine space use (utilisation distributions, UDs). See ‘Methods’ page details. [Define population interest].<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< central function spmapper retrieve estimates absolute proportional quantities prey taken three focal species networks within areas interest user. words, aim tool indicate energetic foraging value marine areas seabirds terms prey consumption shelf-seas scale. primary application outputs includes comparison total prey consumption candidate areas offshore renewable developments, within areas protective conservation measures. outputs can used assist marine spatial planning purposes.

text: list two elements: matrix numeric matrix UD values 462,392 rows 1 column (bird species code). metadataA list 7 elements describing spatial extent resolution: n_rows Number raster rows n_cols Number raster columns x_min Minimum X coordinate x_max Maximum X coordinate y_min Minimum Y coordinate y_max Maximum Y coordinate crs Coordinate reference system WKT PROJ string Wakefield, E.D., Owen, E., Baer, J., Carroll, M.J., Daunt, F., Dodd, S.G., Green, J.., Guilford, T., Mavor, R.., Miller, P.. Newell, M.., 2017. Breeding density, fine‐scale tracking, large‐scale modeling reveal regional distribution four seabird species. Ecological Applications, 27(7), pp.2074-2091.   FAME_UD_standardised_RAZO   Uk-Ireland utilisation distribution (UD) Razorbill (Future Atlantic Marine Environment FAME study period; 2010-2014). Via RSPB; methods, see Wakefi#' object contains matrix UD values associated spatial metadata, build raster  datasets

what: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
text: fn.tot.prey represents model calculates intake prey (kg) single breeding adult seabird across duration chick rearing, based set values describing physiology, ecology demography.

title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
code: fn.tot.prey(   TB_foraging,   TB_flying,   TB_resting_sea,   TB_nest,   ER_foraging,   ER_flying,   ER_resting_sea,   ER_nest,   ER_warming_food,   chick_ER,   chicks_n,   BS_length,   init_mass,   mass_change,   tissue_en_dens,   energy_prey_conv,   assim_effic )

title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
text: TB_foraging Time budget: foraging: % daily time-activity budget spent foraging     (unit: % time) TB_flying Time budget: flying: % daily time-activity budget spent flying    (unit: % time) TB_resting_sea Time budget: rest sea:    % daily time-activity budget spent resting sea    (unit:     % time) TB_nest Time budget: nest:    % daily time-activity budget spent nest    (unit:     % time) ER_foraging Energy requirements: foraging:     Energetic cost full day (24h) foraging    (unit:     kj/day) ER_flying Energy requirements: flying:    Energetic cost full day (24h) flying    (unit:     kj/day) ER_resting_sea Energy requirements: rest sea:    Energetic cost full day (24h) resting sea    (unit:     kj/day) ER_nest Energy requirements: nest:    Energetic cost full day (24h) nest    (unit:     kj/day) ER_warming_food Energy requirements: warming food:    Nominal energetic cost warming food per day    (unit:     kj/day) chick_ER Energy requirements: chick provisioning:    Daily energy needs chicks (.e. provisioned parent birds)    (unit:     kj/day) chicks_n Chicks per nest (breeding success):    Chicks fledged per nest, give seasonal chick provisioning requirements    (unit:     n) BS_length Chick-rearing duration: Duration chick rearing    (unit: days) init_mass Adult body mass:    Mass typical breeding adult    (unit:     g) mass_change Percent adult mass change:    Percentage change adult body mass breeding season    (unit:     % change) tissue_en_dens Adult tissue energy density    Energy density seabird body tissue (adult)    (unit:     kj/g) energy_prey_conv Prey energy density    Energy density prey diet, used convert energy intake prey mass    (unit:     kj/g) assim_effic Digestive assimilation efficiency    Proportion dietary prey energy assimilated adult seabirds    (unit:     proportion)

title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
text: prey intake (kg) single breeding adult seabird duration chick-rearing; argument single numeric value output also single numeric value, arguments vectors vector length length input vector

title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
text: function first calculates daily energy requirements adult seabird, sum : ) weighted average energetic costs core 4 activities (foraging, flight, resting sea, resting colony), according time relative daily time-budget allocation. ii) cost warming daily food load iii) adult's half share chick provisioning requirements, multiplied average number chicks per nest (breeding success) Daily energy requirements scaled duration chick-rearing. Next, energy intake corrected account energy sourced via metabolism body tissue (thus prey consumption; indicated adult body mass change seabird tissue energy density). Total energy energy intake converted prey mass intake according dietary prey energy density, correcting imperfect digestive assimilation. Note, species explicitly specified function, rather function applied set parameter values corresponding given species. Note: argument can either single numeric value vector, vector vectors must length

title: Razorbill sampled parameters — RAZO_sampled_spmapper
text: data frame 60000 rows 17 variables: TB_nest double Time-activity budget: nest TB_flying double Time-activity budget: flight TB_resting_sea double Time-activity budget: rest--sea TB_foraging double Time-activity budget: foraging BS_length integer Number days chick-rearing ER_foraging double Energetic cost: foraging ER_flying double Energetic cost: flight ER_resting_sea double Energetic cost: rest sea ER_nest double Energetic cost: nest ER_warming_food double Energetic cost: warming food chicks_n double Number chicks chick_ER double Daily chick energetic requirement assim_effic double Digestive assimilation efficiency init_mass double Initial adult body mass mass_change double Breeding season change adult body mass tissue_en_dens double Adult seabird tissue energy density energy_prey_conv double Prey energy density

title: Razorbill sampled parameters — RAZO_sampled_spmapper
text: Randomly sampled deviates parameters 'Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper'. See methods details.

title: Seabirds Energetics Parameters — Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper
text: dataset contains information key behavioural physiological traits three focal species seabirds: Common guillemot Uria aalge; Razorbill Alca torda; Black-legged kittiwake Rissa tridactyla. data describe daily time allocation energetic costs core activities energetically important processes species traits. data used spmapper() function estimate mass prey taken individual breeding adult species. See Leedham et al. (2025) full details data sourcing.

title: Seabirds Energetics Parameters — Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper
code: Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper

title: Seabirds Energetics Parameters — Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper
text: data frame 25 rows 4 variables: parameter Character Parameter name Guillemot Numeric Parameter value Guillemot Razorbill Numeric Parameter value Razorbill Kittiwake Numeric Parameter value Kittiwake

title: Seabirds Energetics Parameters — Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper
text: Published dataset: Leedham, O.; Searle, K.R.; Harris, M.P.; Newell, M.; Wanless, S.; Mobbs, D.C.; Butler, .; Daunt, F. (2025). Time-activity budgets energetics common guillemot, razorbill, Atlantic puffin, black-legged kittiwake. what: spmapper core function. Generate prey consumption maps and perform extractions within user-supplied polygons. — spmapper
title: spmapper core function. Generate prey consumption maps and perform extractions within user-supplied polygons. — spmapper
text: Produces prey consumption maps extracts prey mass values within user-specified spatial polygons. Returns list various inputs, intermediate quantities, prey consumption maps extraction totals.

title: spmapper core function. Generate prey consumption maps and perform extractions within user-supplied polygons. — spmapper
code: spmapper(spname, fppolys, popscen, tooldir)

title: spmapper core function. Generate prey consumption maps and perform extractions within user-supplied polygons. — spmapper
text: spname Species name: character string. Must "Guillemot", "Kittiwake" "Razorbill" fppolys Footprint(s): simple feature collection popscen Population scenario: character string. Must "baseline", "low" "high" tooldir Path directory containing tool: character string.

title: spmapper core function. Generate prey consumption maps and perform extractions within user-supplied polygons. — spmapper
text: list, elements: "spname" (species name), "popscen" (population scenario"), "energypars_base_est" (energetics parameters - estimates), "energypars_base_sim" (energetics parameters - simulations), "udmap" (utilisation distribution, raster), "popsize" (population size - number individual breeding adults), "fp_ud_overlap" (proportion UD within polygons/footprints), "onebird_prey_kg_est" (chick-rearing prey intake mass one bird - estimate), "onebird_prey_kg_sim" (chick-rearing prey intake mass one bird - simulations), "allbirds_prey_est" (prey intake mass birds - estimate),  "allbirds_prey_sim" (prey intake birds - simulations), "allbirds_prey_fp_est" (prey mass footprints - estimate),  "allbirds_prey_ _sim" (prey mass footprints - simulations), "prey_cons_map" (prey consumption map - raster)

title: Plot prey consumption maps, with user polygons overlaid (optional) — spmapplot
text: Plot prey consumption maps, user polygons overlaid (optional)

title: Plot prey consumption maps, with user polygons overlaid (optional) — spmapplot
text: rast spatRaster raster object plotted (.e. prey consumption map) polyg optional sf object (.e. user polygons) overlay raster plot (default: NULL).

title: Plot prey consumption maps, with user polygons overlaid (optional) — spmapplot
text: Prey consumption map Western European country polygons (via rnaturalearth), (optional) user input polygons overlaid: ggplot
